hints.content:
There are $\blueD{7}$ packs.

They sold $\greenD{14}$ total yo-yos.

[[☃ image 1]]

What is the $\purpleC{\text{size of the groups}}$?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths. The first tape is labeled 14 and the second tape with 7 equal parts each labeled with a question mark. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the second tape is labeled with the words 7 equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}\times\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}= \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\blueD{7}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{14}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}=\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}$

So, $\greenD{14}\div \blueD{7}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many yo-yos were in each pack are:  

 - $\blueD{7}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{14}$
 - $\greenD{14}\div \blueD{7}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

question.content:
The Juggler Jack store sold $7$ packs of yo-yos yesterday. That was a total of $14$ yo-yos.  Each pack had the same number of yo-yos.

**Which equations would help us find out how many yo-yos are in each pack?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
